title.narrative: Project Preparation and and Development Facility (PPDF)

description.narrative: Infrastruktur ist ein prioritäres Handlungsfeld der Southern African Development Community (SADC). Die Staatengemeinschaft hat im August 2012 den "Regional Infrastructure Develop-ment Master Plan" (RIDMP) verabschiedet. Sie misst diesem die höchste Priorität zur Stärkung des Wirtschaftswachstums und zur Armutsreduzierung im südlichen Afrika bei. Der Projektvor-bereitungsfonds SADC-PPDF (Project Preparation and Development Fund) soll dabei unterstüt-zen den Weg für eine zügige Umsetzung dieses Masterplans zu ebnen. Der SADC-PPDF dient Regierungen und Regionalorganisationen im südlichen Afrika dabei, die Lücke zwischen Projek-tidee und finanzierungsfähigem Vorhaben in den Sektoren Energie- und Wasserversorgung, Transport, Telekommunikation und touristische Infrastruktur zu schließen. Hierzu unterstützt der SADC-PPDF die Erstellung von Studien, die Schaffung von geeigneten Rahmenbedingungen, die Zusammenarbeit von privaten und öffentlichen Akteuren und Capacity Building. Ziel der FZ-Maßnahme ist, öffentliche und private Sponsoren für regionale Infrastrukturprojekte zu gewinnen und das SADC-Sekretariat in seiner Steuerungsfunktion bei der Umsetzung des RIDMP zu stärken. Übergeordnetes entwicklungspolitisches Ziel ist, die wirtschaftliche und poli-tische Integration der SADC-Region zu verbessern. Empfänger und Träger des Vorhabens ist die SADC, vertreten durch das SADC Sekretariat. Die Development Bank of Southern Africa (DBSA) stellt das PPDF Sekretariat und verwaltet den PPDF treuhänderisch. Der SADC-PPDF ist zunächst mit 4,8 Mio. EUR aus der deutschen FZ-Zusage 2004 ausgestattet und mit 6 Mio. Euro aus der Zusage 2015 ausgestattet.

The infrastructure connecting the SADC region is as yet underdeveloped. This compromises the competitiveness of SADC as an economic area; investment has fallen short of expectations. This acts as a brake on further economic growth, job creation and, as a result, income generation. Southern Africa's future economic development hinges on the region having a sound and sustainable infrastructure. That is why SADC members have adopted a Regional Indicative Strategic Development Plan (RISDP), a comprehensive, pro-poor strategy for deepening and determining the course of regional integration. Top priority is given to cross-border infrastructure (transport, energy, telecommunications, tourism). SADC and its member states are currently preparing a SADC Regional Infrastructure Development Master Plan (RIDMP). The RIDMP will identify priority projects and will be used by the SADC Secretariat as the basis for it to perform its role of providing support and advice for the implementation of regional projects of strategic importance. SADC member states, private investors and bilateral and multilateral donors (International Cooperation Partners - ICPs) are, in principle, interested in supporting regional infrastructure projects. So far, however, there has been a lack of thorough and complete feasibility studies and business plans which operators, banks and investors could draw on to make informed decisions on investment, financing or participation. It is thus often difficult to raise sufficient funds for feasibility studies given the risks associated with the early stages of project development. Furthermore, without timely and professional coordination of regional projects during the preparatory phase, planned infrastructure measures can often not be implemented or are subject to considerable delays. The project preparation fund's aim is to facilitate rapid implementation of the RIDMP and boost economic and political integration in the SADC region. In this way, the SADC-PPDF will help SADC and its member states to bridge the gap between project idea and bankable project in the sectors of electricity and water supply, transport, telecommunications and tourist infrastructure. Public and private sponsors for regional infrastructure projects are to be supported in the realisation of the RIDMP. The SADC-PPFD provides grants for the preparation of studies, creation of an appropriate enabling environment, and support for cooperation between the private and public sector and for the necessary capacity-building. The Development Bank of Southern Africa (DBSA) will manage the fund, thus providing the necessary technical expertise. SADC and the DBSA have signed the relevant Memorandum of Understanding. In cooperation with the member states, the DBSA, the KfW and the EUC, the SADC Secretariat has also drawn up operational guidelines setting out all the mechanisms of the Fund and granting the SADC Secretariat (as the owner of the SADC-PPDF) the necessary co-determination and decision-making rights. The Fund is open to further financial contributions from ICPs and the SADC member states.
